While AES can be an interesting place to work for a while it is not a place to develop a career unless you are in one of the operating businesses. The corporate office is characterized by constant turnover, poor management of resources, a reliance on hiring talent instead of developing it and an overall lack of focus. The company prides itself on flexibility, speed and innovation but lacks the leadership skills to manage it. The result is high turnover, favoritism, and low morale. The hardest part of the job is trying to get decisions made. There is an underlying belief that the best decisions come when groups confront each other without guidance on who owns a decision or is responsible for its outcome. People constantly overstep their knowledge base and second guess each other. In general, the company abhors processes and assigned decision rights. The most enjoyable parts are meeting and working with peers from around the world and sharing experiences. If you have the opportunity go work with AES - just don't plan on being there for an extended period.
